headline: Filet Mignon with Rich Balsamic Glaze
description: This is the best filet mignon recipe that includes a rich red wine-balsamic sauce. Perfect for an elegant steak dinner for two in just 15 minutes!

video.description: See how to make an impressive steak dinner for two that's also quick and easy!
video.name: Filet Mignon with Rich Balsamic Glaze

name: Filet Mignon with Rich Balsamic Glaze
recipeIngredient: 0.5 teaspoon ground black pepper, or to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Sprinkle both sides of steaks with pepper and salt.
Heat a nonstick skillet over medium-high heat. Sear steaks in the hot pan until browned, about 1 minute per side.
Reduce heat to medium-low, and pour in balsamic vinegar and red wine. Cover and cook for 4 minutes. Flip steaks and baste with sauce; cover and cook for 4 minutes longer.
Remove steaks to two warmed plates. Spoon a tablespoon of glaze over each steak and serve immediately.

review.reviewBody: Delicious!!!! I followed the recipe. YUM
Love a good steak, and this is the best!!

This well a wonderful meal. My. Husband had seconds. I made this with chicken breast. I was out balsamic so I used red wine vinegar and added mushrooms and brown sugar. I used corn starch to thicken. It well liked. You can use steak I like chicken.
Excellent recipe! The only addition I made was to top it with Bleu Cheese Butter.
I thought this was simple and fantastic! We have a really good local balsamic and I used a malbec from Costco and a couple cloves of garlic. Doubled it as our steaks were larger.
I have been searching for this over 2yrs. I’ve talked this dish up to those that would listen. If you haven’t had this, life is passing you buy. *I used a red blend(3) 1 for the dish & 2 for, well…

This is perfect the way it is. Made on multiple occasions. I make a separate side of sauce for those who want more. I added honey and a teaspoon of cornstarch to the wine and balsamic vinegar. Neighbors loved it, their teenager is asking me for the recipe. This gets 5 stars.
Good cause it's filet mignon, but I think there are better ways to cook it, maybe with way less vinegar.
It was good
Excellent recipe! I used NY Strip Steaks, since they are much cheaper. Still turned out well!
I love easy and good at the same time!
Delicious! So easy to make!
Balsamic glaze just boiled away even with the pan on med-low. Smoked like crazy and nothing special. Will go back to the grill for steaks.
This turned out fantastic, I will be doing this again real soon.

What a waste of money & time. I took the advice of someone else and added garlic & brown sugar to the vinegar & Sherry. can’t imagine anything helping that “glaze.” Way too much vinegar/way too strong. Ruined 2 good filets....

Everyone should know that steak should rest and be at room temperature before cooking. As for true Fillet Mignon it is cooked with a wrapping of bacon around it. Then for medium rare it is cooked 3 minutes, turned and then cooked for 2 minutes then taken of the heat and rested for a few minutes more to allow the juices to develop. Also, served with a mushroom sauce/gravy made with actual mushrooms in the sauce then poured over the top. Served with a light salad on the side and not over-taking the flavour of the steak.
Followed the recipe, turned out beautiful!
I followed the recipe completely...the Filet Mignon was tender, moist, and cooked perfectly! Saved this to my favorites.
Everyone in my family agreed that the balsamic glaze didn't taste very good. If you're having steak, pick a simple steak seasoning instead that will bring out the delicious flavors of the meat!

Son and husband loved this recipe! The balsamic/wine reduction gave it a slight sweetness, which they both commented on. I brought the Seasoned filets to room temperature before searing. Then poured in the balsamic/mix mixture. Served with sautéed onions & mushrooms. They came out so tender you could cut with a butter knife! Will keep this recipe!

I have to say that this is one of my all time favorites for both me and my husband, it's also a winner for a Sunday dinner because it can be made in about a half an hour, who want's to cook all day on a Sunday? I salt and pepper the steaks along with a small amount of granulated garlic then pop them in the refrigerator in the morning, go have fun during the day, return home and it's an easy meal from there. I cook mine in a hot cast iron skillet just a couple of minutes on each side. Ever since I discovered pre-made Balsamic Glaze in a bottle I use this and put the wine in a glass!
Very tasty! It's a winter recipe to me. A rich sauce warms the tummy with home made mashed potatoes and winter squash. thank you!
This recipe has no flavor.

Wonderful! I followed the recipe, but didn’t have red wine, so I used red wine vinegar. After removing the filets from the pan, I added 1TBS butter and 3 TBS brown sugar and reduced the sauce as noted by other reviewers for another 2-3 minutes. I served the sauce as a side instead of pouring it over meat. Delicious! I also rested the meat by removing it from the fridge 20 minutes before cooking and again for several minutes during the sauce reduction. Good tips from previous reviewers!
I made it bacon wrapped. Great flavor in the balsamic glaze!

We love this recipe. I follow the timing directions. However, after I have removed the filets from the wine and vinegar sauce, I add just a touch of butter, about a tablespoon or little less of brown sugar and some rosemary (some may not like the rosemary) I cook that for just a few minutes. It thickens up and the brown sugar cuts the vinegar taste a bit. Great dipping sauce.

This recipe is very simple but very good. The sauce has an excellent consistency and flavor that very nicely complements steak. I served it with Hasselback potatoes and green beans, and it went well with those as well.

One thing I did differently - I wanted to add a little twist to it, so I added a small amount of brown sugar while it was reducing. It worked out great. It very slightly blunted the vinegar and added an element of sweetness that took it to another level. However, it would have worked out great without that as well.
Delicious and so easy

I agree to make at least double the amount of the sauce as it's LOVELY. After I removed steaks from pan I reduced sauce until it was half volume to get it to the perfect glaze consistency so again at least 2x the recipe amount. I served with steamed asparagus and a crab cake.
I love it! The meat is very flavorful, juicy and soft. also very easy to make. Definitely I put this recipe in my cooking routine.
Fantastic!!! I sprinkled it with some Gorgonzola cheese too. It added just the right tang.
this was so good I made it last night for my son and husband they truly enjoyed
Very quick and easy. Makes the most delicious steak you can eat without a knife. So tender and juicy

What a special treat! I used another reviewer's suggestion of a spoonful of brown sugar in the sauce; this was a good idea since I think that balsamic can be pretty tart, and because I knew that the sugar would assist in the sauce caramelization process. I also made 2x the sauce, based on review suggestions. That was also a good idea, to make sure there was plenty. I don't have a cast iron skillet, so I pre-heated my stainless steel oven-proof skillet in a 500 degree oven, and also pre-heated the gas burner I was going to use on the stove-top. That way I get a serious sear, and it didn't take much time to reduce the sauce. Followed the recipe with these changes. Great for special occasion (Valentine's Day), as good as a grill house (without the grill :).
Taste was good. Next time I make it I might thicken the sauce. It was a bit to runny.
Steak cooked to medium PERFECTLY with the exact times given in the recipe. Was my first time cooking filet in the kitchen and is by far one of the best steaks I've ever eaten.

I decided not to cook the steak with the sauce because I knew it would ruin it. Filet should be cooked on its own. I cooked the "glaze" in a seperate pan. It was horrible. It was waay to vinegary even though I added some sugar. It stayed watery and thin, and never thickened to a glaze. This is the first recipe that I have tried off this site that I did not like. I will never make this again!

These were the most tender filets I have had in a long time. I also sprinkled kosher salt on them, let them alone for 45 min. I Then rinsed off the salt, pat dried, and followed the above recipe. Wow great taste!
I made it with four beef tenderloin medallions, so I doubled the balsamic vinegar and red wine. It was so easy and delicious! Everyone loved it! I would definitely make it again!

I took "IMVINTAGE" advice and did the glaze very differently and didn't cook the steaks in it. I was serving 6 steaks so made it with a cup of balsamic and a 1/2 cup merlot and six tablespoons of brown sugar. It took about 20-25 minutes to reduce from almost two cups to less than 1/2 cup but it was worth it! The reduction was thick & syrupy and out of this world delicious and pairing it with melted Gorgonzola on the steak was a HUGE HIT! Served with roasted veggies that were used to sop up every last drop of the glaze. I told all my friends and family about this recipe because it was so easy and soooo delicious! I'll be making the glaze in large quantities next time since it keeps for over a month in the fridge.
Loved it!

It was really good. I halved the recipe because I didn't want leftovers and didn't know if I was going to like it. I don't like wine and don't normally cook with it. This really surprised me and I will definitely be making it again and maybe some adjustments. Thank you for an awesome recipe.
Very delicious. Only added some brown sugar. Will definitely make it again.
Easy, fast and yummy.
My husband and I both loved it.
Best steak ever!
Quick, easy, and very tasty
doubled the balsamic and wine, added 2 cloves of garlic minced - 1 tsp, brown sugar to taste-one spoonful, cooked it over med high heat and reduced until thickened. Lisa really liked.
Delicious
This was a hit and was so easy. The only thing I added was mushrooms, which I cooked separately in butter and some white wine first and then added to the main pan in last few minutes.
So good!
Easy and delicious!
When I made it, I substituted Rib eye steaks instead of Filet Mignon. It turned out great anyway.
Great recipe,makes a nice dinner for 2
Used a nice Woodbridge Cabernet Sauvignon for the glaze as well as to serve with the meal. Beautiful dish, and it tasted exquisite!
This recipe was FABULOUS and I paired it with the oven roasted potatoes and sautéed green beans. My husband said he was Tony the Tiger and us oldsters remember what Tony saiid, “It’s GREAT!!!!!
I followed the recipe exactly as directed and everyone loved it. My steaks came out medium to medium rare which is exactly how we eat a steak. I highly recommend this for a special company dinner.

Rule number 1. You must use a quality balsamic. If you use anything else, you will have a very vinegary flavor. Spend the money, get the good stuff. Your tastebuds will thank you. Rule number 2. let your steaks get to room temperature. It makes a huge difference. The flavor of this recipe was wonderful. I served with with Easy Lemon-Garlic Scallops and steamed asparagus. DELISH!!
I fixed this the other night for my wife and myself, and she loved it! So did I. And it's very simple to make. To round out the meal, I roasted some potatoes and some broccoli.
This recipe was very easy and very good. I made it for my husband's birthday dinner. He loved it!

Meat cooked perfectly but next time I will serve the sauce in a cup on the side. Finishing the filets in the very dark glaze turned the filets too dark and unappealing. So next time I will prepare the meat and glaze separately then serve sauce in the side.

Made it pretty much as is and it come out perfect. My only added touch were fresh crimini mushrooms sliced and sauteed in butter and finished with two Tbs of Maggi sauce. Added mushrooms and sauce to balsamic and wine sauce and topped steaks.
Love the sauce... emailed the recipe to friends.

This recipe is AHHHH-MAZING!! My 11 year old daughter even loved it and she is very picky about steak in general. Sooo easy and delicious!! My daughter’s response was “you need to make this much more often!” Fantastic recipe!!
This was so good!! I will make this again.
I often jazz things up with balsamic vinegar ... never thought of doing it on a filet thought. Delicious.
Delicious and easy!
Delicious and easy!
Made it for Valentine's Day! Came out great! Just be sure that if your filets are larger than what the recipe calls for, cook another couple of minutes.
I would make it again. We loved it!
I used aged Balsamic ,and a bit of worchester it was terrific.

Careful when adding the wine and balsamic. The very hot pan causes a lot of spatter, the sauce/glaze then burned to the pan. 
Second try, turned off the heat at first flip-less of a spatter, but noticed the glaze beginning to scorch again. Added some water to slow the process, which helped. 
Next time I'll thin the glaze a little from the beginning.
We had two prime-cut fillets and the flavors from the balsamic vinegar/red wine glaze was incredible and the steaks practically melted in our mouths. My wife said, "Make it again, please!"

Excellent recipe! I quickly browned the steak in a little high smoke point oil (1-2 minutes each side) which I then poured off and added the balsamic vinegar and the dry red wine. Since I like my steak rare and I was afraid that covering and cooking it would result in well done meat, I quickly concentrated the sauce at medium high heat until it was bubbling and syrupy with the meat in it. Done! Take it off the fire and let the steaks rest 5-10 minutes in the warm skillet. I added two pats of butter during the concentrating of the sauce but that was probably overkill and next time I will try without it. As recommended by others,I doubled the amount of the sauce because it is so good. But PLEASE, PLEASE don't add sugar to the sauce. Balsamic vinegar is rich with natural sugars and once the acetic acid is boiled off you will find it is already quite sweet!
I made it following the recipe with no changes. It was excellent. Will make it again.
I made it and I liked it but the wife didn't like it. Wont make it again.
Folllowed recipe without sauce. Great way to cook! Loved it
Turned out terrific
Terrible waste of a great piece of meat. All we could taste was vinegar.
Certainly I will make it again - it is a fine and easy recipe.

I marinated the steaks for at least 3 hours and they came out amazing!! I cooked them according to the recipe and they were awesome. I was disappointed in the sauce, it cooked up immediately! It definitely did not look like the picture. It had a good flavor. Next time, I may cook the reduction separate and poor over the steaks instead of in the pan with the steaks. I will also double the recipe.
Simple. Excellent. Does not suck. Used cast iron and added a shallot. What the heck. This, mushrooms, and a good cab. A Friday night dinner on a soon to be rainy Thursday.

Delicious balsamic glaze! I seasoned filet mignon with salt and pepper on one side and grilled each of the 2 sides for 3-5 minutes on a high temperature grill until desired temps of 120 for rare and 135.
This was very good and simple
Made the recipe exactly as stated and it was fantastic! Will definitely make again.
I used a very good 25 year aged balsamic from Modena Italy with a local California dry red wine and followed the recipe exactly - this is now my favorite way to prepare a filet Mignon!
I like my filet a bit more well done, but it still came out juicy and delishish with added cook time.
I really disliked this. Balsamic was way too strong and the meat was tough.
Wrapped in bacon, made 8 oz. filets and had to adjust the times a bit, but these were absolutely delicious.

I always read the reviews on recipes prior to making it. I'm an accomplished cook, but do like to see what others liked, or didn't, in efforts to avoid problems. And I often agree with others, about rating a recipe when you tweak it here and there, and yet, here I am. :) 

I used a venison tenderloin, because this time of year, we have a well stocked freezer. I brought it to room temperature, sprinkled with fresh ground pepper, salt and roasted garlic powder, and let it set for about 40 minutes to so. Then placed on the grill. Braising a tenderloin of any kind just toughens the meat.

I sauteed some shallots in a little butter, then removed and added a good quality balsamic vinegar and them hemmed and hawed about a red wine v. Marsala that another reader suggested. I went with the Marsala, which was a great choice, as the slight sweetness really balanced the vinegar. For the reader that found the vinegar overwhelming when cooking, yes! It smells really venaregy (is that even a word?), but, but once the sauce reduces down, it's to die for.

I served the tenderloin with shallots, sauce and a side of steamed green beans and wild rice. This is a great base recipe that will definitely find it's way to our table again.
Loved it! Will definitely make it again!
This is one of my new fav dinners! Very easy and fantastic!
Not as popular in our house as charcoal grilled steaks but still good.
Just quick, yummy tasty and super easy to prepare!!
I was surprised at how well mine turned out!
I didn't care for the sauce!
I made it as the recipe said was very good

Loved it! Incredibly easy. But I would never cook a small filet 4 minutes on each side. I like it more on the rare side. I'm planning on doing this for a small dinner party and certain it will be a hit. Also, easy enough for 'cooking-for-one'.
What's good but not my favorite

item.name: Filet Mignon with Rich Balsamic Glaze
